chapter.label: Atlamol

block.original: Atlamo~`l en gro/`nlenzku
block.translation: The Greenland Ballad of Atli

chapter.block: Many of the chief facts regarding the Atlamol, which follows the Atlakvitha in the Codex Regius, are outlined in the introductory note to the earlier Atli lay. That the superscription in the manuscript is correct, and that the poem was actually composed in Greenland, is generally accepted; the specific reference to polar bears (stanza 17), and the general color of the entire poem make this origin exceedingly likely. Most critics, again, agree in dating the poem nearer 1100 than 1050. As to its state of preservation there is some dispute, but, barring one or two possible gaps of some importance, and the usual number of passages in which the interpolation or omission of one or two lines may be suspected, the Atlamol has clearly come down to us in fairly good shape.

Throughout the poem the epic quality of the story itself is overshadowed by the romantically sentimental tendencies of the poet, and by his desire to adapt the narrative to the understanding of his fellow-Greenlanders. The substance of the poem is the same as that of the Atlakvitha; it tells of Atli's message to the sons of Gjuki, their journey to Atli's home, the slaying of Hogni and Gunnar, Guthrun's bitterness over the death of her brothers, and her bloody revenge on Atli. Thus in its bare out line the Atlamol represents simply the Frankish blending of the legends of the slaughter of the Burgundians and the death of Attila (cf. Gripisspo, introductory note). But here the resemblance ends. The poet has added characters, apparently of his own creation, for the sake of episodes which would appeal to both the men and the women of the Greenland settlement. Sea voyages take the place of journeys by land; Atli is reproached, not for cowardice in battle, but for weakness at the Thing or great council. The additions made by the poet are responsible for the Atlamol's being the longest of all the heroic poems in the Eddic collection, and they give it a kind of emotional vivid ness, but it has little of the compressed intensity of the older poems. Its greatest interest lies in its demonstration of the manner in which a story brought to the North from the South Germanic lands could be adapted to the understanding and tastes of its eleventh century hearers without any material change of the basic narrative.

In what form or forms the story of the Gjukungs and Atli reached the Greenland poet cannot be determined, but it seems likely that he was familiar with older poems on the subject, and possibly with the Atlakvitha itself. That the details which are peculiar to the Atlamol, such as the figures of Kostbera and Glaumvor, existed in earlier tradition seems doubtful, but the son of Hogni, who aids Guthrun in the slaying of Atli, appears, though under another name, in other late versions of the story, and it is impossible to say just how much the poet relied on his own imagination and how far he found suggestions and hints in the prose or verse stories of Atli with which he was familiar.

The poem is in Malahattr (cf. Introduction) throughout, the verse being far more regular than in the Atlakvitha. The compilers of the Volsungasaga evidently knew it in very much the form in which we now have it, for in the main it is paraphrased with great fidelity.

block.original:
Fre`tt hefr o~ld o`fo~`þa`s endr of go/rþu
seggir samkundu:su` vas ny`t fa_e`stum;
o/`xtu einma_e`li,yggt vas þeim si`þan
ok et sama sunum Gju`ka,es vo~`ru sannra`þnir.
block.translation:
There are many who knowhow of old did men
In counsel gather;little good did they get;
In secret they plotted,it was sore for them later,
And for Gjuki's sons,whose trust they deceived.
block.comment: Men: Atli and his advisers, with whom he planned the death of the sons of Gjuki, Gunnar and Hogni. The poet's reference to the story as well known explains the abruptness of his introduction, without the mention of Atli's name, and his reference to Guthrun in stanza 3 simply as ``the woman'' (``husfreyja,'' goddess of the house).
Princes: Atli, Gunnar, and Hogni. Bulwark: Atli's slaying of his wife's brothers, who were ready to support and defend him in his greatness, was the cause of his own death.

block.original:
Horsk vas hu`sfreyja,hugþi at mannviti,
lag heyrþi orþa,hvat a` laun ma_e`ltu;
þa` vas vant vitri,vildi þeim hjalpa:
skyldu of sa_e` sigla,en sjo~lf ne` kvamskat.
block.translation:
Wise was the woman,she fain would use wisdom,
She saw well what meantall they said in secret;
From her heart it was hidhow help she might render,
The sea they should sail,while herself she should go not.
block.comment: The woman: Guthrun, concerning whose marriage to Atli cf. Guthrunarkvitha II. The sea: a late and essentially Greenland variation of the geography of the Atli story. Even the Atlakvitha, perhaps half a century earlier, separates Atli's land from that of the Gjukungs only by a forest.

block.original:
Ru`nar nam ri`sta,rengþi þa_e`r Vingi
---fa`rs vas fly`tandi---,a`þr hann fram seldi;
fo`ru þa` si`þansendimenn Atla
fjarri of fjo~rþ Lima,þars fro/`knir bjoggu.
block.translation:
Runes did she fashion,but false Vingi made them,
The speeder of hatred,ere to give them he sought;
Then soon fared the warriorswhom Atli had sent,
And to Limafjord came,to the home of the kings.
block.comment: Runes: on the two versions of Guthrun's warning, and also on the name of the messenger (here Vingi), cf. Drap Niflunga and note. Limafjord: probably the Limfjord of northern Jutland, an important point in the wars of the eleventh century. The name was derived from ``Eylimafjorþ,'' i.e., Eylimi's fjord. The poet may really have thought that the kingdom of the Burgundians was in Jutland, or he may simply have taken a well-known name for the sake of vividness.

block.original:
O~lva_e`rir urþuok elda kyndu,
hugþu va_e`tr ve`laes vo~`ru komnir;
to`ku þeir fo`rnires þeim fri`þr sendi,
hengþu a` su`lu,hugþut þat varþa.
block.translation:
They were kindly with ale,and fires they kindled,
They thought not of craftfrom the guests who had come;
The gifts did they takethat the noble one gave them,
On the pillars they hung them,no fear did they harbor.
block.comment: Some editors assume a gap after this stanza.

block.original:
Kvam þa` Kostbera---kva_e`n vas ho`n Ho~gna---
kona kapps ga`lig,ok kvaddi þa` ba`þa;
glo`þ vas ok Glaumvo~r,es Gunnarr a`tti,
fellskat saþr sviþri,sy`sti of þo~rf gesta.
block.translation:
Forth did Kostbera,wife of Hogni, then come,
Full kindly she was,and she welcomed them both;
And glad too was Glaumvor,the wife of Gunnar,
She knew well to carefor the needs of the guests.
block.comment: Some editions place this stanza between stanzas 7 and 8. Kostbera (``The Giver of Food'') and Glaumvor (``The Merry''): presumably creations of the poet. Both: Atli's two emissaries, Vingi and the one here unnamed (Knefröth?).

block.original:
Buþu þeir heim Ho~gnaef þa` heldr fo/`ri:
sy`n vas svipvi`si,ef þeir si`n ga_e`þi;
he`t þa` ferþ Gunnarr,ef Ho~gni vildi,
Ho~gni þvi` hli`tti,es hinn of re`þi.
block.translation:
Then Hogni they askedif more eager he were,
Full clear was the guile,if on guard they had been;
Then Gunnar made promise,if Hogni would go,
And Hogni made answeras the other counseled.
block.comment: It is altogether probable that a stanza has been lost between stanzas 6 and 7, in which Gunnar is first invited, and replies doubtfully. Made promise: many editions emend the text to read ``promised the journey.'' The text of line 4 is obscure; the manuscript reads ``nitti'' (``refused''), which many editors have changed to ``hlitti,'' which means exactly the opposite.

No gap is indicated in the manuscript; Bugge adds (line 3):
Then the warriors rose,and to slumber made ready.
(risu at þat rekkar,re`þusk þeir at sofna.)
The manuscript indicates line 4 as beginning a new stanza, and some editions make a separate stanza out of lines 1--2. Others suggest the loss of a line after line 4.

block.original:
Kend vas Kostbera,kunni skil ru`na,
inti orþstafiat eldi ljo~sum;
ga_e`ta varþ tungui` go`ma ba`þa:
vo~`ru sva` viltar,at vas vant at ra`þa.
block.translation:
Wise was Kostbera,and cunning in rune-craft,
The letters would she readby the light of the fire;
But full quickly her tongueto her palate clave,
So strange did they seemthat their meaning she saw not.
block.comment: The manuscript does not indicate line 1 as the beginning of a stanza; cf. note on stanza 8.

block.original:
Sa_eing fo`ru si`þansi`na þau Ho~gni
dreymþi dro`ttla`ta,dulþi þess va_e`tki,
sagþi horsk hilmi,þegars ho`n re`þ vakna:
block.translation:
Full soon then his bedcame Hogni to seek,
The clear-souled one dreamed,and her dream she kept not,
To the warrior the wise onespake when she wakened:
block.comment:
Some editions combine this stanza with lines 1--2 of stanza 11. The manuscript indicates no gap. Grundtvig adds (line 2):
But sleep to the womanso wise came little.
(seint um sofnaþisvinn hu`sfreyja.)

block.original:
``Heiman go/risk, Ho~gni!hygg þu` at ro~`þum
---fa`r es fullry`ninn!---far i` sinn annat!
re`þ ek þa_e`r ru`nares reist þi`n systir:
bjo~rt hefr þe`r eigiboþit i` sinn þetta.
block.translation:
``Thou wouldst go hence,Hogni, but heed my counsel,---
Known to few are the runes,---and put off thy faring;
I have read now the runesthat thy sister wrote,
And this time the bright onedid not bid thee to come.
block.comment: Some editions make a separate stanza out of lines 1--2, or combine them with stanza 10, and combine lines 3--4 with stanza 12 (either lines 1--4 or 1--2). The manuscript marks line 3 as beginning a new stanza.

block.original:
Eitt ek mest undrumk:ma`kat enn hyggja,
hvat þa` varþ vitri,es skyldi vilt ri`sta;
sva` vas a` vi`sat,sem undir va_e`ri
bani ykkarr beggja,ef bra`þla kva_e`miþ.
[vant es stafs vi`fi,eþa valda aþrir.]''
block.translation:
Full much do I wonder,nor well can I see,
Why the woman wiseso wildly hath written;
But to me it seemsthat the meaning beneath
Is that both shall be slainif soon ye shall go.
But one rune she missed,or else others have marred it.''
block.comment: Line 5 may be spurious, or else all that is left of a lost stanza. The manuscript marks it as the beginning of a new stanza, which, as the text stands, is clearly impossible.

block.original:
``Allar'u illu`þgar,a`kkak þess kynni,
vilkak la_e`s leita,nema launa eigim;
okkr mun gramr gollireifa glo`þrauþu,
oumk ek aldrigi,þo`t ve`r o`gn fregnim.''
block.comment: The manuscript, followed by some editions, has ``Hogni spake'' in the middle of line 1. Ill: the manuscript and many editions have ``this.'' The king: Atli.

block.original:
``Stopalt munuþ ganga,ef it stundiþ þangat,
ykkr mun a`stkynnieigi i` sinn þetta;
dreymþi mik, Ho~gni!---dyljumk þat eigi---:
ganga mun anda_e`ris,eþa ella hra_e`þumk.
block.translation:
``In danger ye fare,if forth ye go thither,
No welcoming friendlythis time shall ye find;
For I dreamed now, Hogni,and nought will I hide,
Full evil thy faring,if rightly I fear.
block.comment: The manuscript does not indicate the speakers in this dialogue between Kostbera and Hogni (stanzas 14--19). Two line, may possibly have been lost after line 2, filling out stanza 14 and making stanza 15 (then consisting of lines 3--4 of stanza 14 and lines 1--2 of stanza 15) the account of Kostbera's first dream. The manuscript marks line 3 as beginning a new stanza. In any case, the lost lines cannot materially have altered the meaning.

block.original:
Bla_e`ju sa`k þi`nabrinna i` eldi,
hryti ho`r logihu`s mi`n i` go/gnum.''
Ho~gni kvaþ:
``Liggja li`nkla_e`þiþaus e`r litt ro/`kiþ:
þau munu bra`tt brinna,þars þu` bla_e`ju sa`tt.''
block.translation:
Thy bed-covering saw Iin the flames burning,
And the fire burst highthrough the walls of my home.''
Hogni spake:
``Yon garment of linenlies little of worth,
It will soon be burned,so thou sawest the bed-cover.''
block.comment: Saw I: the manuscript here, as also in stanzas 16, 18, 21, 22, and 24, has ``methought,'' which involves a metrical error. Some editors regard lines 3--4 as the remains of a four-line stanza. Regarding Kostbera's warning dreams, and Hogni's matter-of-fact interpretations of them, cf. Guthrunarkvitha II, 39--44.

block.original:
``Bjo~rn sa`k inn kominn,bryti upp stokka,
hristi sva` hramma,at ve`r hra_e`dd yrþim;
munni oss mo~rg hefþi,sva`t ma_e`ttim etki:
þar vas ok þro~mmunþeygi sva` li`til.''
block.translation:
``A bear saw I enter,the pillars he broke,
And he brandished his clawsso that craven we were;
With his mouth seized he many,and nought was our might,
And loud was the tumult,not little it was.''
block.comment: The meaning of the first half of line 3 in the original is obscure.

block.original:
``Veþr mun þar vaxa,verþa o`tt snimma:
hvi`tabjo~rn hugþir---þar mun hregg austan.''
block.translation:
``Now a storm is brewing,and wild it grows swiftly,
A dream of an ice-bearmeans a gale from the east.''
block.comment: Two lines may have been lost after line 2, but the Volsungasaga paraphrase gives no clue. Ice-bear: polar bears, common in Greenland, are very rarely found in Iceland, and never in Norway, a fact which substantiates the manuscript's reference to Greenland as the home of the poem.

The manuscript indicates no gap, but most editors assume the loss of a line after line 1 or 2; Grundtvig adds, after line 1:
Black were his feathers,with blood was he covered.
(svo~rtum va_e`ngjum,sveita vas hann mjo~k stokkinn.)
Atli's spirit: the poet's folk-lore seems here a bit weak. Presumably he means such a female following-spirit (``fylgja'') as appears in Helgakvitha Hjorvarthssonar, prose following stanza 34 (cf. note thereon), but the word he uses, ``hamr'' (masculine) means ``skin,'' ``shape.'' He may, however, imply that Atli had assumed the shape of an eagle for this occasion.

block.original:
``Slo~`trum sy`sliga,se::um þa` roþru:
opt's þat fyr o/xnum,es o~rnu dreymir;
heill es hugr Atla,hvatkis þik dreymir.''
Lokit þvi` le`tu,li`ddi hver ro/`þa.
block.translation:
``They will slaughter soon,and so blood do we see,
Oft oxen it meanswhen of eagles one dreams;
True is Atli's heart,whatever thou dreamest.''
Then silent they were,and nought further they said.
block.comment: The manuscript indicates line 4 as beginning a new stanza.

block.original:
Vo~knuþu velborin,vas þar sams do/`mi,
ga_e`ttisk þess Glaumvo~r,at va_e`ri grand svefna.
viþ Gunnarrat faa tva_e`r leiþir.
block.translation:
The high-born ones wakened,and like speech they had,
Then did Glaumvor tellhow in terror she dreamed,
Gunnartwo roads they should go.
block.comment: The manuscript indicates no gap, but none of the many attempted emendations have made sense out of the words as they stand. The proper location for the missing words is sheer guesswork. Two roads: probably the meaning is that their way (i.e., their success) would be doubtful.

The manuscript does not indicate the speakers in this dialogue (stanzas 21--26). No gap is indicated after line 2. Most editors assume the loss of two lines or of a full stanza after stanza 21 giving Gunnar's interpretation of Glaumvor's dream, but the Volsungasaga gives no clue, as it does not mention this first dream at all. Grundtvig suggests as Gunnar's answer:
Banners are gleaming,since of gallows didst dream,
And wealth it must meanthat thou serpents didst watch.
(Gna_e`fir gunnfani,þar er þu` galga hugþir,
auþr mun o/`rinn,þar er orma dreymir.)
Gods' doom: an odd, and apparently mistaken, use of the phrase ``ragna rök'' (cf. Voluspo, introductory note).

block.original:
``Blo`þgan sa`k ma_e`kiborinn o`r serk þi`num
---illt es svefn sli`kansegja nauþmanni---,
geir hugþak standai` go/gnum þik miþjan,
emjuþu ulfara` endum bo~`þum.''
block.translation:
``A sword drawn bloodyfrom thy garments I saw,---
Such a dream is hardo a husband to tell,---
A spear stood, methought,through thy body thrust,
And at head and feetthe wolves were howling.''

block.original:
``Rakkar þar rinna,ra`þask mjo~k geyja,
opt verþr glaumr hundafyr geira flaugun.''
block.translation:
``The hounds are running,loud their barking is heard,
Oft hounds' clamor followsthe flying of spears.''
block.comment: Perhaps two lines have been lost after line 2. Possibly the concluding phrase of line 2 should be ``bloody spears,'' as in the Volsungasaga paraphrase.

block.original:
O~` sa`k inn rinnaat endlo~ngu hu`si,
þyti af þjo`sti,þeystisk of bekki,
bryti fo/`tr ykkrabro/`þra he`r tveggja,
go/rþit vatn va_e`gja:vesa mun þat fyr nekkvi.''
block.translation:
``A river the lengthof the hall saw I run,
Full swiftly it roared,o'er the benches it swept;
O'er the feet did it breakof ye brothers twain,
The water would yield not;some meaning there was.''
block.comment: Again Gunnar's interpretation is missing, and most editors either assume a gap or construct two Malahattr lines (out of the Volsungasaga prose paraphrase, which runs: ``The grain shall flow, since thou hast dreamed of rivers, and when we go to the fields, often the chaff rises above our feet.'' (``Þar munu renna akrar, er þu` hugþir a`na, ok er ve`r go~ngum akrinn, nema opt sto`rar agnir fo_etr va`ra.'')

block.original:
``Konur hugþak dauþarkoma i` no~`tt hingat,
va_e`ri vart bu`nar,vildi þik kjo`sa,
byþi þe`r bra`þligatil bekkja sinna:
ek kveþ aflimaorþnar þe`r di`sir.''
block.translation:
``I dreamed that by nightcame dead women hither,
Sad were their garments,and thee were they seeking;
They bade thee come swiftlyforth to their benches,
And nothing, methinks,could the Norns avail thee. ''
block.comment: The meaning of line 4 is uncertain, but apparently it refers to the guardian spirits or lesser Norns (cf. Fafnismol, 12--13 and notes).

block.original:
``Seinat's at segja,sva` es nu` ra`þit:
forþumka furþu,alls þo`'s fara a_e`tlat,
mart es mjo~k gli`kligtat munim skamma_eir.''
block.translation:
``Too late is thy speaking,for so is it settled
From the faring I turn not,the going is fixed,
Though likely it isthat our lives shall be short.''
block.comment: Possibly a line has been lost from this stanza.

block.original:
Litu es ly`sti,le`tusk þeir fu`sir
allir upp ri`sa,o~nnur þau lo~ttu;
fo`ru fimm saman,---fleiri til vo~`ru
ho~lfu hu`skarlar---:hugat vas þvi` illa.
block.translation:
Then bright shone the morning,the men all were ready,
They said, and yet eachwould the other hold back;
Five were the warriors,and their followers all
But twice as many,---their minds knew not wisdom.
block.comment: Five: Gunnar, Hogni, and the three mentioned in stanza 28.

block.translation:
Snævar and Solar,they were sons of Hogni,
Orkning was he calledwho came with the others,
Blithe was the shield-tree,the brother of Kostbera;
The fair-decked ones followed,till the fjord divided them,
Full hard did they plead,but the others would hear not.
block.comment:
Perhaps a line has been lost before line 1; Grundtvig supplies:
Gunnar and Hogni,the heirs twain of Gjuki.
(Gunnarr ok Ho~gni,Gju`ka arfar ba`þir.)
Snævar (the manuscript here has ``Snevar''), Solar and Orkning appear only in this poem and in the prose narratives based on it. Lines 2--3 may have been expanded out of one line, or possibly line 3 is spurious. The manuscript indicates line 4 as beginning a new stanza, and many editions make a separate stanza out of lines 4--5, many of them assuming the loss of two lines. Shield-tree: warrior (Orkning), here identified as Kostbera's brother. Fair-decked ones: women, i.e., Glaumvor and Kostbera. Fjord: perhaps specifically the Limafjord mentioned in stanza 4.

block.original:
Glaumvo~r kvaþ at orþi,es Gunnarr a`tti,
ma_e`lti viþ Vinga,sem henni vert þo`tti:
``Veitkak ef verþ launiþat vilja ossum;
glo/`pr es gests kva`ma,ef i` go/risk nekkvat.''
block.translation:
Then did Glaumvor speak forth,the wife of Gunnar,
To Vingi she saidthat which wise to her seemed:
``I know not if wellthou requitest our welcome,
Full ill was thy comingif evil shall follow.''

block.original:
Svarþi þa` Vingi,se`r re`þ litt eira
:
``Eigi hann jo~tnar,ef at yþr lygi,
galgi go~rvallan,ef a` griþ hygþi!''
block.translation:
Then did Vingi swear,and full glib was his speech,
``May giants now take meif lies I have told ye,
And the gallows if hostilethought did I have.''
block.comment:
The manuscript indicates no gap. Grundtvig inserts (line 2):
The evil was clearwhen his words he uttered.
(opin vas þo` illu`þ,es hann orþ ma_e`lti.)

block.original:
Bera kvaþ at orþibli`þ i` hug si`num
``Sigliþ e`r sa_e`lirok sigr of a`rniþ,
fari sem fyrir ma_e`lik,fa_e`sk eigi þvi` ni`ta!''
block.translation:
Then did Bera speak forth,and fair was her thought,
``May ye sail now happy,and victory have,
To fare as I bid ye,may nought your way bar.''
block.comment:
Bera: Kostbera; the first element in compound feminine proper names was not infrequently omitted; cf. Hild for Brynhild (Helreith Brynhildar, 6). The manuscript indicates no gap; Grundtvig inserts (line 2):
And clear was her cryto her kinsmen dear.
(niþjum na`bornumnam ho`n gott gala.)

block.original:
Ho~gni þat ma_e`lti,hugþi gott no~`num:
``Huggizk it, horskar!hve`gis þat go/rvisk;
ma_e`la þat margir,missir þo` sto`rum:
mo~rgum ra_e`þr litlu,hve` verþr leiddr heiman.''
block.translation:
Then Hogni made answer,---dear held he his kin,---
``Take courage, ye wise ones,whatsoever may come;
Though many may speak,yet is evil oft mighty,
And words avail littleto lead one homeward.''
block.comment: Hogni's method of cheering his wife and sister-in-law is somewhat unusual, for the meaning of lines 3--4 is that good wishes and blessings are of little use in warding off danger.

block.original:
So~usk til si`þan,a`þr i` sundr hyrfi;
þa` hykk sko~p skiptu,skilþusk vegir þeira.
block.translation:
They tenderly lookedtill each turned on his way,
Then with changing fatewere their farings divided.
block.comment:
Perhaps two lines have been lost after line 2; Grundtvig supplies:
Then weeping didGlaumvor go to her rest-bed,
And sadly did Beraher spinning wheel seek.''
(Glaumvo~r gra`tandigekk til hvi`lbeþjar,
Bera brosandiborþa nam rekja.)

block.original:
Roa no~`mu ri`ki,rifu kjo~l halfan,
beystu bakfo~llum,brugþusk heldr reiþir;
ho~mlur slitnuþu,hai::r brotnuþu,
go/rþut far festa,a`þr þeir fra` hyrfi.
block.translation:
Full stoutly they rowed,and the keel clove asunder,
Their backs strained at the oars,and their strength was fierce;
The oar-loops were burst,the thole-pins, were broken,
Nor the ship made they fastere from her they fared.
block.comment: Keel, etc.: in the Nibelungenlied, and presumably in the older German tradition, Hagene breaks his oar steering the Burgundians across the Danube (stanza 1564), and, after all have landed, splinters the boat (stanza 1581) in order that there may be no retreating. The poet here seems to have confused the story, connecting the breaking of the ship's keel with the violence of the rowing, but echoing the older legend in the last line, wherein the ship is allowed to drift away after the travellers have landed. Oar-loops: the thongs by which the oars in a Norse boat were made fast to the thole-pins, the combination taking the place of the modern oarlock.

block.original:
Litlu ok lengra---lok munk þess segja---
bo/` so~u þeir standaes Buþli a`tti;
ho`tt hrikþu grindir,es Ho~gni kni`þi,
orþ kvaþ þa` Vingi,þats o~`n betr va_e`ri.
block.comment: The manuscript indicates line 4 as beginning a new stanza, and many editions combine it with stanza 36, some of them assuming the loss of a line from stanza 35. In the Volsungasaga paraphrase the second half of line 4 is made a part of Vingi's speech: ``Better had ye left this undone.''

block.original:
``Fariþ firr hu`si---fla`tt es til so/`kja,
bra`tt hefk ykkr brenda,bragþs skuluþ e`r ho~ggnir,
fagrt baþk ykkr kvo~`mu,fla`tt vas þo` undir---
ella heþan bi`þiþ,meþan ho/kk yþr galga!''
block.translation:
``Go ye far from the house,for false is its entrance,
Soon shall I burn you,ye are swiftly smitten;
I bade ye come fairly,but falseness was under,
Now bide ye afarwhile your gallows I fashion.''
block.comment: Cf. note on preceding stanza; the manuscript does not indicate line 1 as beginning a stanza. Line 3 may be spurious.

block.original:
Hitt kvaþ þa` Ho~gni,hugþi litt va_e`gja,
varr at vettugi,es varþ at reyna:
``Hirþa oss hra_e`þa,haf þat fram sjaldan!
ef þu` eykr orþi,illt munt þe`r lengja.''
block.translation:
Then Hogni made answer,his heart yielded little,
And nought did he fearthat his fate held in store:
``Seek not to affright us,thou shalt seldom succeed;
If thy words are more,then the worse grows thy fate.''
block.comment: In the Volsungasaga paraphrase the second half of line 1 and the first half of line 2 are included in Hogni's speech.

block.original:
Hrundu þeir Vingaok i` hel dro~`þu,
o/xar at lo~gþu,meþan i` o~nd hixti.
block.translation:
Then Vingi did they smite,and they sent him to hell,
With their axes they clove himwhile the death rattle came.
block.comment: Possibly two lines have been lost after line 2.

block.original:
Flykþusk þeir Atliok fo~ru i` brynjur,
gengu sva` go~rvir,at vas garþr milli.
block.translation:
Atli summoned his men,in mail-coats they hastened,
All ready they came,and between was the courtyard.
block.comment: It is probable that a considerable passage has been lost between stanzas 39 and 40, for the Volsungasaga paraphrase includes a dialogue at this point. The manuscript indicates no gap, and most editions combine stanzas 39 and 40 as a single stanza. The prose passage, indicating the substance of what, if any thing, is lost, runs as follows: ```Be welcome among us, and give me that store of gold which is ours by right, the gold that Sigurth had, and that now belongs to Guthrun.' Gunnar said: `Never shalt thou get that gold, and men of might shalt thou find here, ere we give up our lives, if it is battle thou dost offer us; in truth it seems that thou hast prepared this feast in kingly fashion, and with little grudging toward eagle and wolf.''' The demand for the treasure likewise appears in the Nibelungenlied.

block.original:
Urþusk a` orþumallir senn reiþir:
``gengu sva` go~rvir,at vas garþr milli.''
block.translation:
Then came they to words,and full wrathful they were:
``Long since did we planhow soon we might slay you.''
block.comment: These two lines, which most editions combine with stanza 39, may be the first or last two of a four-line stanza. The Volsungasaga gives Atli's speech very much as it appears here.

The manuscript does not indicate the speaker; Grundtvig adds as a first line:
Then Hogni laughed loudwhere the slain Vingi lay.
(Hlo` þa` Ho~gni,ste` of hra_e` Vinga.)
Many editors assume the loss of a line somewhere in the stanza. Unarmed: Hogni does not see Atli's armed followers, who are on the other side of the courtyard (stanza 39). One: Vingi.

block.original:
O`þir þa` urþu,es þat orþ heyrþu:
forþuþu fingrumok fengu i` sno/`ri,
skutu skarpligaok skjo~ldum hli`fþusk.
block.comment: Most editors assume the loss of one line, after either line 1 or line 3.

block.original:
Inn kvam andspilli,hvat u`ti dry`gþu
hvatir fyr ho~llu:heyrþu þra_e`l segja;
o~tul vas þa` Guþru`n,es ekka heyrþi,
hlaþin halsmenjum:hreytti go~rvo~llum,
[slo/ngþi sva` silfri,at i` sundr hrutu baugar.]
block.translation:
In the house came the wordhow the heroes with out
Fought in front of the hall;they heard a thrall tell it;
Grim then was Guthrun,the grief when she heard,
With necklaces fair,and she flung them all from her,
[The silver she hurledso the rings burst asunder.]
block.comment:
The manuscript reading of lines 1--2, involving a metrical error, is:
In the house came the wordof the warring without,
Loud in front of the hallthey heard a thrall shouting.
Some editors assume a gap of two lines after line 2, the missing passage giving the words of the thrall. The manuscript marks line 3 as the beginning of a stanza, and many editions make a separate stanza of lines 3--5, same of them assuming the loss of a line after line 3. With the stanza as here given, line 5 may well be spurious.

block.original:
U`t gekk ho`n si`þan,ypþit litt hurþum
---fo`ra fa_e`lt þeygi---ok fagnaþi komnum;
hvarf til Hniflunga---su` vas hinzt kveþja---,
fylgþi saþr sli`ku,sagþi mun fleira:
block.translation:
Then out did she go,she flung open the doors,
All fearless she went,and the guests did she welcome;
To the Niflungs she went---her last greeting it was,---
In her speech truth was clear,and much would she speak.
block.comment: Niflungs: regarding the application of this term to the Burgundians cf. Atlakvitha, 11, and Brot, 17, and notes. The manuscript here spells the name with an initial N, as elsewhere, but in stanza 83 the son of Hogni appears with the name ``Hniflung.'' In consequence, some editors change the form in this stanza to ``Hniflungs,'' while others omit the initial H in both cases. I have followed the manuscript, though admittedly its spelling is illogical.

block.original:
``Leitaþak i` li`knaat letja ykkr heiman:
sko~pum viþr mangi,skuluþ þo` he`r komnir.''
Ma_e`lti af mannviti,ef mundu sa_e`ttask,
etki at re`þusk,allir ni` kvo~`þu.
block.translation:
``For your safety I soughtthat at home ye should stay;
None escapes his fate,so ye hither must fare.''
Full wisely she spake,if yet peace they might win,
But to nought would they hearken,and ``No'' said they all.

block.original:
Sa` þa` sa_e`lborin,at þeir sa`rt le`ku,
hugþi a` harþra_e`þiok hrauzk o`r skikkju;
no/kþan to`k ma_e`kiok niþja fjo~r varþi,
ho/`g vasat at hjaldri,hvars ho`n hendr festi.
block.translation:
Then the high-born one sawthat hard was their battle,
In fierceness of heartshe flung off her mantle;
Her naked sword grasped sheher kin's lives to guard,
Not gentle her handsin the hewing of battle.
block.comment: The warlike deeds of Guthrun represent an odd transformation of the German tradition. Kriemhild, although she did no actual fighting in the Nibelungenlied, was famed from early times for her cruelty and fierceness of heart, and this seems to have inspired the poet of the Atlamol to make his Guthrun into a warrior outdoing Brynhild herself. Kriemhild's ferocity of course, was directed against Gunther and especially Hagene, for whose slaying she rather than Etzel was responsible; here, on the other hand, Guthrun's is devoted to the defense of her brothers.

block.original:
Do`ttir le`t Gju`kadrengi tva` hni`ga,
bro`þur hjo` Atla,bera varþ þann si`þan;
[skapþi sva` sko/`ru,skeldi fo`t undan;]
annan re`þ ho~ggva,sva`t sa` upp reisat,
i` helju þann hafþi:þeygi hendr skulfu.
block.translation:
Then the daughter of Gjukitwo warriors smote down,
Atli's brother she slew,and forth then they bore him;
[So fiercely she foughtthat his feet she clove off;]
Another she smoteso that never he stood,
To hell did she send him,---her hands trembled never.
block.comment: Line 3 is very likely an interpolation. The manuscript marks line 4 as the beginning of a new stanza, and some editions make a separate stanza of lines 4--5. Atli's brother: doubtless a reminiscence of the early tradition represented in the Nibelungenlied by the slaying of Etzel's brother, Blœdelin (the historical Bleda), by Dancwart.

block.original:
Þjo~rku þat go/rþu,þeiri vas viþ brugþit,
bra` of allt annates unnu bo~rn Gju`ka;
Hniflunga kvo~`þu,meþan heilir lifþu,
[sko`pu so`kn sverþum,slitusk af brynjur,]
hjoggu sva` hjalma,sem þeim hugr dygþi.
block.translation:
Full wide was the fameof the battle they fought,
'Twas the greatest of deedsof the sons of Gjuki;
Men say that the Niflungs,while themselves they were living,
With their swords fought mightily,mail-coats they sundered,
And helms did they hew,as their hearts were fearless.
block.comment: Line 3 may well be spurious, for it implies that Gunnar and Hogni were killed in battle, whereas they were taken prisoners. Some editors, in an effort to smooth out the inconsistency, change ``themselves'' in this line to ``sound.'' Line 5 has also been questioned as possibly interpolated. Niflungs: on the spelling of this name in the manuscript and the various editions cf. note on stanza 44.

block.original:
Morgin mest vo~`gu,unz miþjan dag li`ddi,
[o`ttu allaok o~ndurþan dag,]
fyrr vas fullvegit,flo`þi vo~llr blo`þi:
a`tja`n, a`þr fellu,o/fri firum urþu
Beru tveir sveinarok bro`þir hennar.
block.translation:
All the morning they foughtuntil midday shone,
[All the dusk as welland the dawning of day,]
When the battle was ended,the field flowed with blood;
Ere they fell, eighteenof their foemen were slain,
By the two sons of Beraand her brother as well.
block.comment: Line 2 is probably an interpolation, and the original apparently lacks a word. There is some obscurity as to the exact meaning of lines 4--5. The two sons of Bera: Snævar and Solar; her brother is Orkning; cf. stanza 28.

block.original:
Ro~skr to`k at ro/`þa,þo`t hann reiþr va_e`ri:
``Illt es umb li`task,yþr es þat kenna;
vo~`rum þri`r tigir,þegnar vi`gligir,
eptir lifa ellifu:o`r es þar brunnit.
block.translation:
Then the warrior spake,and wild was his anger:
``This is evil to see,and thy doing is all;
Once we were thirty,we thanes, keen for battle,
Now eleven are left,and great is our lack.
block.comment: The warrior: Atli. Thirty: perhaps an echo of the ``thirty warriors'' of Thjothrek (cf. Guthrunarkvitha III, 5). Subtracting the eighteen killed by Snævar, Solar and Orkning (stanza 49), and Vingi, killed by the whole company (stanza 38), we have eleven left, as Atli says, but this does not allow much for the exploits of Gunnar and Hogni, who, by this reckoning, seem to have killed nobody. The explanation probably is that lines 4--5 of stanza 49 are in bad shape.

block.original:
Bro/`þr vo~`rum fjo`rir,es Buþla mistum:
hefr nu` Hel halfa:ho~ggnir tveir liggja;
ma_e`gþ gat ek mikla;ma`kak þvi` leyna,
konu va`liga:kna`kak þess njo`ta.
block.translation:
There were five of us brotherswhen Buthli we lost,
Now Hel has the half,and two smitten lie here;
A great kinship had I,---the truth may I hide not,---
From a wife bringing slaughtersmall joy could I win.
block.comment: Five brothers: the Volsungasaga speaks of four (not five) sons of Buthli, but names only Atli. Regarding the death of the first two brothers cf. stanza 91 and note. The manuscript marks line 3 as beginning a stanza, and many editions combine lines 3--4 with stanza 52. Some insert lines 2--3 of stanza 52 ahead of lines 3--4 of stanza 51.

Possibly a line has been lost from this stanza. The manuscript marks line 3 as beginning a new stanza, which is impossible unless something has been lost. Gold: the meaning of this half line is somewhat doubtful, but apparently Atli refers to Sigurth's treasure, which should have been his as Brynhild's brother. Sister: Brynhild; regarding Guthrun's indirect responsibility for Brynhild's death cf. Gripisspo, 45 and note.

block.translation:
``Hear me now, Atli!the first evil was thine;
My mother didst thou take,and for gold didst murder her,
My sister's daughterthou didst starve in a prison.
A jest does it seemthat thy sorrow thou tellest,
And good do I find itthat grief to thee comes.''
block.comment: The manuscript does not name the speaker. The Volsungasaga gives the speech, in somewhat altered form, to Hogni: ``Why speakest thou so? Thou wast the first to break peace; thou didst take my kinswoman and starved her in a prison, and murdered her and took her wealth; that was not kinglike; and laughable does it seem to me that thou talkest of thy sorrow, and good shall I find it that all goes ill with thee.'' This presumably represents the correct form of the stanza, for nowhere else is it intimated that Atli killed Guthrun's mother, Grimhild, nor is the niece elsewhere mentioned. Some editions make a separate stanza of lines 4--5, Grundtvig adding a line after line 3 and two more after line 5. Other editors are doubtful about the authenticity of either line 3 or line 5.

block.original:
``Eggjak yþr, jarlar!auka harm sto`rum
vi`fs ens vegliga:viljak þat li`ta;
kostiþ sva` keppa,at klo/kkvi Guþru`n,
sea þat ma_e`ttak,at se`r ne` ynþit.
block.translation:
``Go now, ye warriors,and make greater the grief
Of the woman so fair,for fain would I see it;
So fierce be thy warringthat Guthrun shall weep,
I would gladly beholdher happiness lost.
block.comment: The manuscript does not indicate the speaker.

block.original:
Takiþ e`r Ho~gnaok hyldiþ meþ kni`fi,
skeriþ o`r hjarta,skuluþ þess go~rvir;
Gunnar grimmu`þgana` galga festiþ,
belliþ þvi` bragþi,bjo`þiþ til ormum!''
block.translation:
Seize ye now Hogni,and with knives shall ye hew him,
His heart shall ye cut out,this haste ye to do;
And grim-hearted Gunnarshall ye bind on the gallows,
Swift shall ye do it,to serpents now cast him.''

block.original:
``Go/r sem til lystir,glaþr munk þess bi`þa:
ro~skr munk þe`r reynask,reynt hefk fyrr brattan;
ho~fþuþ þa` hnekking,meþan heilir vo~`rum:
nu` 'rum sva` sa`rir,at ma`tt sjalfr valda.''
block.translation:
``Do now as thou wilt,for glad I await it,
Brave shalt thou find me,I have faced worse before;
We held thee at baywhile whole we were fighting,
Now with wounds are we spent,so thy will canst thou work.''
block.comment: The text of the first half of line 3 is somewhat uncertain, but the general meaning of it is clear enough.

block.original:
Beiti þat ma_e`lti,bryti vas hann Atla:
``To~kum ve`r Hjalla,en Ho~gna forþum!
ho~ggum halfyrkjan!hann es skapdauþi,
lifira sva` lengi,lo~skr mun a_e` heitinn.''
block.translation:
Then did Beiti speak,he was Atli's steward:
``Let us seize now Hjalli,and Hogni spare we!
Let us fell the sluggard,he is fit for death,
He has lived too long,and lazy men call him.''
block.comment: Beiti: not elsewhere mentioned. The Atlakvitha version of this episode (stanzas 23--25) does not mention Beiti, and in the Volsungasaga the advice to cut out Hjalli's heart instead of Hogni's is given by an unnamed ``counsellor of Atli.'' In the Atlakvitha Hjalli is actually killed; the Volsungasaga combines the two versions by having Hjalli first let off at Hogni's intercession and then seized a second time and killed, thus introducing the Atlakvitha episode of the quaking heart (stanza 24). The text of the first half of line 3 is obscure, and there are many and widely varying suggestions as to the word here rendered ``sluggard.''

block.original:
Hra_e`ddr vas hverga_e`tir,helta in lengr ru`mi,
kunni klo/kkr verþa,kleif i` ro~` hverja;
vesall le`zk vi`gs þeira,es skyldi va`ss gjalda,
ok sinn dag dapran,at deyja fra` svi`num,
[allri orkostues hann a`þr hafþi].
block.translation:
Afraid was the pot-watcher,he fled here and yon,
And crazed with his terrorhe climbed in the corners:
``Ill for me is this fighting,if I pay for your fierceness,
And sad is the dayto die leaving my swine
And all the fair victualsthat of old did I have.''
block.comment: Some editions mark line 5 as probably interpolated.

block.original:
To`ku bra`s Buþlaok brugþu til kni`fi,
o/`pþi illþra_e`li,a`þr odds of kendi;
to`m le`zk at eigateþja vel garþa,
vinna et vergasta,ef hann viþ re`tti.
[feginn le`zk þo` Hjalli,at hann fjo~r þa_e`gi].
block.comment: Cook: the original word is doubtful. The Volsungasaga does not paraphrase lines 3--5; the passage may be a later addition, and line 5 is almost certainly so.

block.original:
Ga_e`ttisk þess Ho~gni---go/rva sva` fa_e`ri---
at a`rna a`nauþgum,at undan gengi:
``Fyr kveþk me`r minnaat fremja leik þenna:
hvi` mynim he`r viljaheyra a` þa` skra_e`ktun?''
block.translation:
Then fain was Hogni---there are few would do thus---
To beg for the slavethat safe hence he should go;
``I would find it far betterthis knife-play to feel,
Why must we all harkto this howling longer?''

block.original:
Þrifu þeir þjo`þgo`þan:þa` vas kostr engi
rekkum rakklo~`tumra`þ enn lengr dvelja;
hlo` þa` Ho~gni,heyrþu dagmegir,
keppa sva` kunni,kvo~l hann vel þolþi.
block.translation:
Then the brave one they seized;to the warriors bold
No chance was there leftto delay his fate longer;
Loud did Hogni laugh,all the sons of day heard him,
So valiant he wasthat well he could suffer.
block.comment: It is probable that a stanza describing the casting of Gunnar into the serpents' den has been lost after this stanza. Sons of day: the phrase means no more than ``men.''

block.translation:
A harp Gunnar seized,with his toes he smote it
So well did he strikethat the women all wept,
And the men, when clearthey heard it, lamented;
Full noble was his song,the rafters burst asunder.
block.comment: Regarding Gunnar's harp-playing, and his death, cf. Oddrunargratr, 27--30 and notes, and Atlakvitha, 34. Toes (literally ``sole-twigs''): the Volsungasaga explains that Gunnar's hands were bound. Rafters: thus literally, and probably correctly; Gering has an ingenious but unlikely theory that the word means ``harp.''

block.original:
Dou þa` dy`rir:dags vas heldr snimma:
le`tu a` lestilifa i`þro`tta.
block.translation:
Then the heroes diedere the day was yet come;
Their fame did they leaveever lofty to live.
block.comment:
There is some doubt as to the exact meaning of line 2. After this line two lines may have been lost; Grundtvig adds:
Few braver shall everbe found on the earth,
Or loftier menin the world ever give.
(fa`ir munu fro/`knaria` fold koma
ne` menn ma_e`trifyrir mold ofan.)

block.original:
Sto`rr þo`ttisk Atli,ste` of þa` ba`þa,
horskri harm sagþiok re`þ heldr at bregþa:
``Morginn's nu`, Guþru`n!mist hefr þe`r hollra,
sums est sjalfskapa,at hafi sva` gengit.''
block.translation:
Full mighty seemed Atlias o'er them he stood,
The wise one he blamed,and his words reproached her:
``It is morning, Guthrun;now thy dear ones dost miss,
But the blame is part thinethat thus it has chanced.''
block.comment: Wise one: Guthrun. The manuscript marks line 3 as beginning a new stanza.

block.original:
``Feginn estu, Atli!ferr þu` vi`g ly`sa:
a` munu þe`r iþrar,ef þu` allt reynir;
su` mun erfþ eptir,ek kann þe`r segja:
ills gengsk þe`r aldri,nema ek ok deyja.''
block.translation:
``Thou art joyous, Atli,for of evil thou tellest,
But sorrow is thineif thou mightest all see;
Thy heritage heavyhere can I tell thee,
Sorrow never thou losestunless I shall die.''
block.comment: The manuscript does not indicate the speaker.

block.original:
``Kannka sli`ks synja;se`k til ra`þ annat
ho~lfu ho`gligra---ho~fnum opt go`þu---:
mani munk þik hugga,ma_e`tum a`ga_e`tum,
silfri sna_e`hvi`tu,sem þu` sjo~lf vilir.''
block.translation:
``Not free of guilt am I;a way shall I find
That is better by far,---oft the fairest we shunned;---
With slaves I console thee,with gems fair to see,
And with silver snow-white,as thyself thou shalt choose.''
block.comment: The manuscript does not name the speaker. The negative in the first half of line 1 is uncertain, and most editions make the clause read ``Of this guilt I can free myself.'' The fairest, etc.: i. e., I have often failed to do the wise thing.

block.original:
``O`n es þess engia_e` vilk þvi` ni`ta:
sleit ek þa` sa`ttir,es vo~ru sakar minni;
afko~`r a`þr þo`ttak:a` mun nu` go/`þa,
hra_e`fþak of hotvetna,meþan Ho~gni lifþi.
block.translation:
``No hope shall this give thee,thy gifts I shall take not,
Requital I spurnedwhen my sorrows were smaller;
Once grim did I seem,but now greater my grimness,
There was nought seemed too hardwhile Hogni was living.
block.comment: The manuscript does not indicate the speaker. Requital, etc.: it is not clear just to what Guthrun refers; perhaps she is thinking of Sigurth's death, or possibly the poet had in mind his reference to the slaying of her mother in stanza 53.

block.original:
Alin vit upp vo~`rumi` einu hu`si,
le`kum leik marganok i` lundi o`xum,
go/`ddi okkr Gri`mhildrgolli ok halsmenjum:
bana munt me`r bro/`þrabo/`ta aldrigi
[ne` vinna þess etki,at me`r vel þykki].
block.translation:
Our childhood did we havein a single house,
We played many a game,in the grove did we grow;
Then did Grimhild give usgold and necklaces,
Thou shalt ne'er make amendsfor my brother's murder,
Nor ever shalt win meto think it was well.
block.comment: Line 5 is very probably a later addition, though some editors question line 3 instead.

block.original:
Kostum drepr kvennakarla ofri`ki,
i` kne` gengr hnefi,ef kvistir þverra,
tre` tekr at hni`ga,ef ho/ggr to~`g undan:
nu` ma`tt einn, Atli!o~llu he`r ra`þa.''
block.translation:
But the fierceness of menrules the fate of women,
The tree-top bows lowif bereft of its leaves,
The tree bends overif the roots are cleft under it;
Now mayest thou, Atli,o'er all things here rule.''
block.comment:
Guthrun suddenly changes her tone in order to make Atli believe that she is submissive to his will, and thus to gain time for her vengeance. Line 2 in the original is thoroughly obscure; it runs literally:
On the knee goes the fistif the twigs are taken off.
Perhaps the word meaning ``fist'' may also have meant ``tree-top,'' as Gering suggests, or perhaps the line is an illogical blending of the ideas contained in lines 1 and 3.

block.original:
Gno`tt vas grunny`þgi,es gramr þvi` tru`þi,
sy`n vas svipvi`si,ef hann si`n ga_e`þi;
kro~pp vas þa` Guþru`n,kunni of hug ma_e`la,
le`tt ho`n se`r go/rþi,le`k ho`n tveim skjo~ldum.
block.translation:
Full heedless the warriorwas that he trusted her,
So clear was her guileif on guard he had been;
But crafty was Guthrun,with cunning she spake,
Her glance she made pleasant,with two shields she played.
block.comment: The manuscript indicates line 3 as the beginning of a new stanza. Two shields, etc.: i. e., Guthrun concealed her hostility (symbolized by a red shield, cf. Helgakvitha Hundingsbana I, 34) by a show of friendliness (a white shield).

block.original:
O_Exti o~ldrykkjurat erfa bro/`þr si`na,
samr le`zk ok Atliat si`na go/rva;
lokit þvi` le`tu,lagat vas drykkju,
su` vas samkundaviþ svo~rfun ofmikla.
block.translation:
The beer then she broughtfor her brothers' death feast,
And a feast Atli madefor his followers dead
No more did they speak,the mead was made ready,
Soon the men were gatheredwith mighty uproar.
block.comment: Many editions make a separate stanza of lines 1--2, some of them suggesting the loss of two lines, and combine lines 5--4 with lines 1--2 of stanza 72. The manuscript marks both lines 1 and 3 as beginning stanzas.

block.original:
Steo~ng vas sto`rhuguþ,stri`ddi a_e`tt Buþla,
vildi ver si`numvinna ofrhefndir:
lokkaþi litlaok lagþi viþ stokki,
glu`pnuþu grimmirok gre`tu þeygi,
fo`ru i` faþm mo`þur,fre`ttu hvat skyldi.
block.comment: The manuscript marks line 3 as beginning a new stanza; some editions make a separate stanza of lines 3--5, while others combine them with lines 1--2 of stanza 73. Line 2 in the original is clearly defective, the verb being omitted. The meaning of line 3 is uncertain; the Volsungasaga paraphrase has: ``At evening she took the sons of King Atli (Erp and Eitil) where they were playing with a block of wood.'' Probably the text of the line as we have it is faulty. Lines 4--5 may possibly have been expanded out of a single line, or line 5 may be spurious.

block.original:
``Spyriþ litt eptir!spilla a_e`tlak bo~`þum,
lyst vo~rumk þess lengiat lyfja ykkr elli.''
Sveinarnir kva`þu:
``Blo`tt sem vilt bo~rnum,bannar þat mangi,
sko~mm mun ro` reiþi,ef reynir go~rva.''
block.translation:
``Nay, ask me no more!You both shall I murder,
For long have I wishedyour lives to steal from you.''
The boys spake:
``Slay thy boys as thou wilt,for no one may bar it,
Short the angry one's peaceif all thou shalt do.''
block.comment: The manuscript does not name the speakers. It indicates line 3 as beginning a new stanza, in which it is followed by many editions. The Volsungasaga paraphrases line 4 thus: ``But it is shameful for thee to do this.'' Either the text of the line has been changed or the Volsungasaga compilers misunderstood it. The angry one: Atli.

block.original:
Bra` þa` barno/`skubro/`þra en kappsvinna,
skiptit skapliga,skar a` hals ba`þa;
enn fre`tti Atli,hvert farnir va_e`ri
sveinar hans leika,es sa` þa` hvergi.
block.translation:
Then the grim one slew bothof the brothers young,
Full hard was her deedwhen their heads she smote off;
Fain was Atli to knowwhither now they were gone,
The boys from their sport,for nowhere he spied them.
block.comment: The manuscript indicates line 3 as beginning a new stanza.

block.original:
``Yfir ro~`þumk gangaAtla til segja,
dylja mun þik eigido`ttir Gri`mhildar;
glaþa munat þik, Atli!ef go~rva reynir:
vakþir vo~` mikla,es va`tt bro/`þr mi`na.
block.translation:
``My fate shall I seek,all to Atli saying,
The daughter of Grimhildthe deed from thee hides not;
No joy thou hast, Atli,if all thou shalt hear,
Great sorrow didst wakewhen my brothers thou slewest.
block.comment: The manuscript does not name the speaker.

block.original:
Svaf ek mjo~k sjaldan,si`þans þeir fellu,
he`t ek þe`r ho~rþu,hefk þik nu` mintan;
morgin me`r sagþir,mank enn þann go~rva:
nu` es auk aptann,a`tt sli`kt at fre`tta.
block.translation:
I have seldom sleptsince the hour they were slain,
Baleful were my threats,now I bid thee recall them;
Thou didst say it was morning,---too well I remember,---
Now is evening come,and this question thou askest.
block.comment: Morning: Guthrun refers to Atli's taunt in stanza 64.

block.original:
Maga hefr þu` þinnamist
sem þu` si`zt skyldir;
hausa veizt þeirahafþa at o~lsko~`lum,
dry`gþak sva` drykkju,dreyra blettk þeira.
block.translation:
Now both of thy sonsthou hast lost
as thou never shouldst do;
The skulls of thy boysthou as beer-cups didst have,
And the draught that I made theewas mixed with their blood.
block.comment:
The manuscript indicates no gap (lines 1--2), and most editions make a single line, despite the defective meter:
Thy sons hast thou lostas thou never shouldst lose them.
The second part of line 2 is in the original identical with the second half of line 3 of stanza 80, and may perhaps have been inserted here by mistake. Skulls: it is possible that line 3 was borrowed from a poem belonging to the Völund tradition (cf. Völundarkvitha, 25 and 37), and the idea doubtless came from some such source, but probably the poet inserted it in a line of his own composition to give an added touch of horror. The Volsungasaga follows the Atlamol in including this incident.

block.original:
To`kk þeira hjo~rtuok a` teini steikþak,
seldak þe`r si`þan,sagþak at kalfs va_e`ri:
einn þu` þvi` ollir,etki re`tt leifa,
to~ggtu ti`þliga,tru`þir vel jo~xlum.
block.translation:
I cut out their hearts,on a spit I cooked them,
I came to thee with them,and calf's flesh I called them;
Alone didst thou eat them,nor any didst leave,
Thou didst greedily bite,and thy teeth were busy.
block.comment: Some editions add lines 3--4 to stanza 79; Finnur Jonsson marks them as probably spurious.

block.original:
Barna veizt þinna:biþr se`r fa`r verra;
hlut veld ek mi`num,ho/`lumk þo` etki.''
block.translation:
Of thy sons now thou knowest;few suffer more sorrow;
My guilt have I told,fame it never shall give me.''
block.comment: Perhaps these two lines should form part of stanza 78, or perhaps they, rather than lines 3--4 of stanza 78, are a later addition. A gap of two lines after line 1 has also been conjectured.

block.original:
``Grimm vastu, Guþru`n!es go/rva sva` ma`ttir,
barna þinna blo`þiat blanda me`r drykkju;
sny`tt hefr sifjungum,sem þu` si`zt skyldir,
me`r la_e`tr ok sjo~lfummillum ills li`tit.''
block.translation:
``Grim wast thou, Guthrun,in so grievous a deed,
My draught with the bloodof thy boys to mingle;
Thou hast slain thine own kin,most ill it be seemed thee,
And little for metwixt my sorrows thou leavest.''
block.comment: The manuscript does not indicate the speaker.

block.original:
``Vili me`r enn va_e`riat vega þik sjalfan:
fa`tt es fullillafarit viþ gram sli`kan;
dry`gt þu` fyrr hafþir,þats do/`mi vissut
heimsku, harþra_e`þii` heimi þessum.
[nu` hefr enn aukitþats a`þan fro~`gum,
greipt hefr glo/`p sto`ran,go~rt hefr þitt erfi.]''
block.translation:
``Still more would I seekto slay thee thyself,
Enough ill comes seldomto such as thou art;
Thou didst folly of old,such that no one shall find
In the whole world of mena match for such madness.
Now this that of latewe learned hast thou added,
Great evil hast grasped,and thine own death feast made.''
block.comment:
The manuscript does not indicate the speaker. Lines 1--2 may be the remains of a separate stanza; Grundtvig adds:
Thou wast foolish, Atli,when wise thou didst feel,
Ever the wholeof thy race did I hate.
(Heimskr vastu, Atli!es þu` horskri vel tru`þir,
a_e`tt þinni allrihefik a_e` hatat.)
The Volsungasaga paraphrase, however, indicates no gap. Many editions make a separate stanza of lines 3--6, which, in the Volsungasaga, are paraphrased as a speech of Atli's. Lines 5--6 may be spurious.

block.original:
``Brend munt a` ba`liok bariþ a`þr grjo`ti:
þa` hefr þu` a`rnatþats þu` a_e` beiddisk.''
Guþru`n kvaþ:
``Seg þu` þe`r sli`karsorgir a`r morgin:
fri`þra vilk dauþafara i` ljo`s annat.''
block.translation:
``With fire shall they burn thee,and first shall they stone thee,
So then hast thou earnedwhat thou ever hast sought for.''
Guthrun spake:
``Such woes for thyselfshalt thou say in the morning,
From a finer death Ito another light fare.''
block.comment: The manuscript does not indicate the speakers. Many editions make two separate stanzas of the four lines. Another light: a fairly clear indication of the influence of Christianity; cf. Introductory Note.

block.original:
So~`tu samty`nis,sendusk fa`rhugi,
hendusk heiptyrþi,hva`rtki se`r unþi;
heipt o`x Hniflungi,hugþi a` sto`rra_e`þi,
gat fyr Guþru`nu,at va_eri grimmr Atla.
block.translation:
Together they satand full grim were their thoughts,
Unfriendly their words,and no joy either found;
In Hniflung grew hatred,great plans did he have,
To Guthrun his angeragainst Atli was told.
block.comment: The manuscript marks line 3 as the beginning of a new stanza. Hniflung: the Volsungasaga says that ``Hogni had a son who was called Hniflung,'' but the name appears to be nothing more than the familiar ``Niflung'' applied in general to the sons of Gjuki and their people. On the spelling cf. note on stanza 44. This son of Hogni appears in later versions of the story. In the Thithrekssaga he is called Aldrian, and is begotten by Hogni the night before his death. Aldrian grows up and finally shuts Attila in a cave where he starves to death. The poet here has incorporated the idea, which finds no parallel in the Atlakvitha, without troubling himself to straighten out the chronology.

block.original:
Kvo~`mu i` hug henniHo~gna viþfarar,
talþi happ ho~`num,ef hann hefnt ynni;
veginn vas þa` Atli---vas þess skamt bi`þa---:
sunr va` Ho~gnaok sjo~lf Guþru`n.
block.translation:
To her heart came everthe fate of Hogni,
She told him 'twere wellif he vengeance should win;
So was Atli slain,---'twas not slow to await,---
Hogni's son slew him,and Guthrun herself.
block.comment: Line 4 may be in Fornyrthislag, and from another poem.

block.original:
Ro~skr to`k at ro/`þa,rakþisk o`r svefni,
kendi bra`tt benja,bands kvaþ þo~rf o/nga:
``Segiþ et sannasta:hverr va` sun Buþla?
emkak litt leikinn,li`fs telk vo~`n o/nga.''
block.translation:
Then the warrior spake,as from slumber he wakened,
Soon he knew for his woundswould the bandage do nought:
``Now the truth shalt thou say:who has slain Buthli's son?
Full sore am I smitten,nor hope can I see.''
block.comment: The manuscript marks line 3 as beginning a new stanza. The Volsungasaga makes line 2 part of Atli's speech.

block.original:
''[Dylja mun þik eigido`ttir Gri`mhildar:]
lo~`tumk þvi` valda,es li`þr þi`na a_e`vi,
en sumu sunr Ho~gna,es þik so~`r mo/`þa.''
Atli kvaþ:
``Vaþit hefr at vi`gi,þo`t va_e`rit skapligt:
illt es vin ve`laþanns þe`r vel trui::r.
block.translation:
``Ne'er her deed from thee hidesthe daughter of Grimhild,
I own to the guiltthat is ending thy life,
And the son of Hogni;'tis so thy wounds bleed.''
Atli spake:
``To murder hast thou fared,though foul it must seem;
Ill thy friend to betraywho trusted thee well.
block.comment:
The manuscript does not name the speakers. It marks line 4 as the beginning of a new stanza, and many editions follow this arrangement, in most cases making a stanza of lines 4--5 and line 1 of stanza 87. However, line 1 may well have been interpolated here from stanza 75. Grundtvig adds after line 3:
His father he avenged,and his kinsmen fully.
(hefndi hann sva` fo~þurok fra_e`nda sinna allra.)
Some editors assume the loss of one or two lines after line 5.
The manuscript marks line 2 as beginning a new stanza, and some editions make a stanza out of lines 2--4 and line 1 of stanza 88.

block.original:
Allt vas i`tarligtof o`rar ferþir,
margs vas alls so`mimanna ti`ginna;
naut vo~`ru o/`rin,nutum af sto`rum,
þar vas fjo~lþ fear,fengu til margir.
block.translation:
Most noble was allwhen of old we journeyed,
Great honor did we haveof heroes full worthy;
Of cattle had we plenty,and greatly we prospered,
Mighty was our wealth,and many received it.
block.comment: The manuscript marks line 2 as the beginning of a stanza, and many editions make a stanza out of lines 2--4, or combine them with stanza 89. Some question the genuineness of line 4.

Many editions assume a gap of one line after line 3; Grundtvig adds:
Bit-champing horsesand wheel-wagons bright.
(mara me`lgreypa,marga hvelvagna.)
Line 4 may be spurious. Greater: i. e., the silver which Atli gave Guthrun was of greater value even than the honor of receiving such royal gifts. Line 4 may be spurious.

block.original:
Le`zt þe`r allt þykkjasem etki va_e`ri,
meþan lo~nd þau lo~`gues me`r leifþi Buþli;
[gro`ftu sva` undir,go/rþit hlut þiggja;]
sva_e`ru le`zt þi`nasitja opt gra`tna,
fannka i` hug heilumhjo`na va_e`tr si`þan.''
block.comment: Some editions mark line 3 as spurious or defective. The manuscript marks line 4 as the beginning of a new stanza. The land, etc.: there is much obscurity as to the significance of this line. Some editors omit or question ``me,'' in which case Atli is apparently reproaching Guthrun for having incited him to fight with his brothers to win for himself the whole of Buthli's land. In stanza 91 Guthrun denies that she was to blame for Atli's quarrels with his brothers. The Volsungasaga reading supports this interpretation. The historical Attila did actually have his brother, Bleda, killed in order to have the sole rule. The treasure: Sigurth's hoard, which Atli claimed as the brother of Brynhild and husband of Guthrun, Sigurth's widow, but which Gunnar and Hogni kept for themselves, with, as Atli here charges, Guthrun's connivance. My mother: the only other reference to Atli's mother is in Oddrunargratr, 30, wherein she appears as the adder who stings Gunnar to death, and in the prose passages based on that stanza.

block.original:
``Ly`gr þu` nu`, Atli!þo`t þat litt ro/`kjak:
heldr vask ho/`g sjaldan,ho`fsk þu` þo` sto`rum;
bo~rþusk bro/`þr ungir,bo~`rusk ro`g milli,
halft gekk til heljaro`r hu`si þi`nu.
[hroldi hotvetnaþats til hags skyldi].
block.comment: The manuscript does not indicate the speaker. It marks both lines 4 and 5 as beginning new stanzas, but line 5 is presumably an interpolation. The text of the second half of line 2 is obscure, and many emendations have been suggested. Ye brothers: cf. note on stanza 90. Half: i. e., two of Atli's brothers were killed, the other two dying in the battle with Gunnar and Hogni; cf. stanza 51.

block.original:
Þriu vo~`rum systkin,þo`ttum o`va_e`gin,
fo`rum af landi,fylgþum Sigurþi;
ska_e`va ve`r le`tum,skipi hvert va`rt sty`rþi,
o~rkuþum at auþnu,unz ve`r austr kvo~`mum.
block.translation:
My two brothers and Iwere bold in our thoughts,
From the land we went forth,with Sigurth we fared;
Full swiftly we sailed,each one steering his ship,
So our fate sought we e'ertill we came to the East.
block.comment: From the land: this maritime expedition of Guthrun and her two brothers, Gunnar and Hogni (the poet seems to know nothing of her half-brother, Gotthorm), with Sigurth seems to have been a pure invention of the poet's, inserted for the benefit of his Greenland hearers. Nothing further is reported concerning it.

block.original:
Konung dro~`pum fyrstan,kurum land þaþra,
hersar a` ho~nd gengu:hra_e`zlu þat vissi;
vo~`gum o`r sko`giþanns vildum syknan,
settum þann sa_e`lanes se`r ne` a`ttit.
block.translation:
First the king did we slay,and the land we seized,
The princes did us service,for such was their fear;
From the forest we calledthem we fain would have guiltless,
And rich made we manywho of all were bereft.
block.comment: The forest: i. e., men who were outlawed in the conquered land were restored to their rights---another purely Norse touch.

block.original:
Dauþr varþ enn hunski:drap þa` bra`tt kosti,
strangt vas angr ungriekkju nafn hljo`ta;
kvo~l þo`tti kvikriat koma i` hu`s Atla,
a`tti a`þr kappi,illr vas sa` missir.
block.translation:
Slain was the Hun-king,soon happiness vanished,
In her grief the widowso young sat weeping;
Yet worse seemed the sorrowto seek Atli's house,
A hero was my husband,and hard was his loss.
block.comment: Hun-king: Sigurth, though most illogically so called; cf. Sigurtharkvitha en skamma, 4 and note. The Volsungasaga paraphrase of line 2 is so remote as to be puzzling: ``It was little to bear the name of widow.'' Perhaps, however, the word ``not'' fell out between ``was'' and ``little.''

block.original:
Kvamtat af þingi,es ve`r þat fra_e`gim,
at þu` so~k so/`ttirne` slo/`gþir aþra:
vildir a_e` va_e`gja,en va_e`tki halda,
kyrt of þvi` la`ta''
block.translation:
From the Thing thou camst never,for thus have we heard,
Having won in thy quarrels,or warriors smitten;
Full yielding thou wast,never firm was thy will,
In silence didst suffer,''
block.comment: Thing, etc.: here the poet makes Atli into a typical Norse land-owner, going to the ``Thing,'' or general law council, to settle his disputes. Even the compilers of the Volsungasaga could not accept this, and in their paraphrase changed ``Thing'' to ``battle.'' The text of the second half of line 2 is uncertain. The manuscript leaves a blank to indicate the gap in-line 4; Grundtvig adds: ``as beseems not a king.'' (es konungr skyldit.)

block.original:
``Ly`gr þu` nu`, Guþru`n!litt mun viþ bo/`task
hluti hva`rigra:ho~fum o~ll skarþan;
go/rþu nu`, Guþru`n!af go/`zku þinni
okkr til a`ga_e`tis,es mik u`t hefja.''
block.translation:
``Thou liest now, Guthrun,but little of good
Will it bring to either,for all have we lost;
But, Guthrun, yet oncebe thou kindly of will,
For the honor of both,when forth I am home.''

block.original:
``kno~rr mun ek kaupaok kistu steinda,
vexa vel bla_e`ju,at verja þitt li`ki,
hyggja a` þo~rf hverja,sem vit holl va_e`rim.''
block.translation:
``A ship will I buy,and a bright-hued coffin,
I will wax well the shroudto wind round thy body,
For all will I careas if dear were we ever.''
block.comment: The manuscript does not indicate the speaker. Many editors assume a gap either before or after line 1. A ship: the burial of Norse chiefs in ships was of frequent occurrence, but the Greenland poet's application of the custom to Atli is some what grotesque.
Heirs, etc.: merely a stock phrase, here quite meaningless, as Atli's heirs had all been killed. Long: cf. Guthrunarhvot, introductory prose.

block.original:
Sa_e`ll es hverr si`þan,es sli`k getr fo/`þa
jo`þ at afreki,sem es o`l Gju`ki:
lifa mun þat eptira` landi hverju
þeira þra`ma_e`li,hvargis þjo`þ heyrir.
block.translation:
Full happy shall he bewho such offspring has,
Or children so gallant,as Gjuki begot;
Forever shall live,and in lands far and wide,
Their valor heroicwherever men hear it.
